title: Receiving Feedback
description: Explore how you respond when your partner raises concerns with you.

questions.text: When my partner raises a concern about something I did, my first reaction is usually...
choices: To listen and try to understand
To feel defensive and explain myself
To feel hurt or criticized
Depends on how they bring it up

therapeutic.rationale: First reactions to feedback reveal defensiveness patterns. Listeners stay open; defenders protect; hurt-feelers personalize; delivery-dependent types are conditional. Defensiveness is one of Gottman's Four Horsemen.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The listener may not understand why their partner gets defensive; the defensive partner may feel attacked. Work on creating safety for feedback.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared first reactions create predictability about how feedback conversations start.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you typically react when your partner raises a concern? What's happening inside you?

questions.text: When I feel defensive, I tend to...
choices: Explain why I did what I did
Point out what they did wrong too
Shut down and withdraw
Get upset or emotional

therapeutic.rationale: Defensive behaviors vary. Explainers justify; counter-attackers deflect; withdrawers escape; emoters express distress. All block hearing your partner's concern. Recognizing your pattern is the first step to changing it.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different defensive patterns have different impacts. Counter-attacking escalates; withdrawing leaves issues unresolved. Both need attention.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared defensive pattern helps you recognize when you're both doing it.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What do you do when you feel defensive? What's behind that behavior?

questions.text: What helps me receive feedback without getting defensive is...
choices: When it's delivered gently and kindly
When I feel secure in the relationship
When I have time to process before responding
When I remind myself my partner is on my team

therapeutic.rationale: Conditions for non-defensiveness vary. Gentle-delivery needers require soft startup; security-needers require relationship safety; processors need time; reminder-needers use cognitive reframing. Knowing your conditions helps your partner give feedback effectively.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different conditions are fineâ€”your partner can adjust delivery while you work on your reception. Meet in the middle.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared conditions make supporting each other's feedback reception easier.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What helps you stay open when receiving feedback? What can your partner do? What can you do?

questions.text: The hardest feedback for me to hear is about...
choices: How I made my partner feel
Patterns I keep repeating
Things that feel core to who I am
Times when I was unaware I hurt them

therapeutic.rationale: Feedback sensitivities reveal vulnerabilities. Impact-feedback is hard when you didn't intend harm; pattern-feedback feels like character indictment; core-identity feedback feels existential; unawareness-feedback triggers shame. Knowing your sensitivity helps you prepare.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different sensitivities mean different vulnerabilities. Be extra gentle with your partner's sensitive areas.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared sensitivity creates mutual understanding about what's hardest to hear.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What feedback is hardest for you to receive? Why is that particular type so difficult?

questions.text: I want to get better at receiving feedback because...
choices: I want my partner to feel heard
I know it helps us grow together
I don't want defensiveness to damage us
I want to be a better partner

therapeutic.rationale: Motivation for growth affects commitment. Partner-focusers prioritize their partner's experience; growth-focusers see relationship development; damage-avoiders prevent harm; self-improvers want personal growth. All motivations can drive positive change.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different motivations are all valid and can coexist. What matters is the commitment to improving.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared motivation aligns your reasons for working on feedback reception.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Why do you want to get better at receiving feedback? What would be different if you did?
